>>14996414
Easiest method is here below if you know calculus.

Let 10 be the length of one side of the square, and [math]A[/math] be the area of the shaded region. We choose this length because it simplifies the relevant points in our coordinate system greatly, and we want to find the answer with calculus.

The left side of the square will run along our y axis, and the x axis will biject the left and right sides of the square. Thus the top left corner of the square is at point (5,0) and the center of the square is at the point (0,5). Now we can find the boundary curves of the red shaded region.

The region is bounded on the left by the curve [math]\sqrt{25-{x}^{2}}[/math], from above by [math]\sqrt{100-{x}^{2}}-5[/math], and from below by [math]5-\sqrt{25-{(x-5)}^{2}}[/math].

Set [math]\sqrt{100-{x}^{2}}-5 = 5-\sqrt{25-{(x-5)}^{2}}[/math] to find that [math]x=8[/math], then plug that into [math]\sqrt{100-{x}^{2}}-5[/math] to find [math]\sqrt{100-{8}^{2}}-5=1[/math]. Thus the coordinate of their intersection is [math](8,1)[/math].

Thus [math]A = \int_{0}^8 {\sqrt{100-{x}^{2}}-5}dx - \int_{0}^5 \sqrt{25-{x}^{2}}dx - \int_{5}^8 5-\sqrt{25-{(x-5)}^{2}}dx[/math]

Because we're not doing a homework problem, here's the mathematica code to get the answer.

f[x_] = Sqrt[100 - x^2] - 5
g[x_] = 5 - Sqrt[25 - (x - 5)^2]
h[x_] = Sqrt[25 - x^2]
N[Integrate[f[x], {x, 0, 8}] - Integrate[g[x], {x, 5, 8}] -
Integrate[h[x], {x, 0, 5}]]

This should output is 9.77357, and we are done.

threads.com:
What's your take on the Grabby Aliens Model? According to it, as soon as an expansionary alien civilization arises, all systems they get their hands on will be inevitably colonized by them. No new intelligence life has a chance to evolve because every planet gets occupied by space-faring advanced life. This constitutes a selection effect.

Therefore, expansionary aliens sets a deadline for other natural-born intelligence species to ever appear.

The model can also be used to predict the speed of aggressive expansion. If we could see aliens in our sky, it would be evidence that they expand slowly. If they expand really fast, you wouldn't see them until they are in your face. The lack of evidence for alien activity even on nearby galaxy through our telescope, counterintuitively, implies a diabolically fast rate of expansion (a third of the speed of light).

The implication is that alien civilization that will be born naturally are and will be born in a very short time window after which no more natural evolutions will occur. Simulations of the model indicate that the rare earliest civilizations would have also the chance to expand wider both because of lack of competition and the universe being smaller in size. As much as 30%-50% of the universe's volume, each controlling [math]10^5 - 3x10^7[/math] galaxies could be already colonized, and we could face them in an estimate of 500 million years.

This offers an explanation for our apparent earliness in the history of the universe. There are no aliens nearby because otherwise we wouldn't be here.

>>14995057


I think you are confusing the state of P and Q with the state of the implication. Intuitively. It is a given that the implication holds.
Think of it as the truth table is asking if the implication holds. If the implication is denied, then the value of P=>Q is false.
So there is only one situation that denies the implication; when P being true and Q being false. In the last two cases, the only thing that matters is that P is false. No one cares about Q under the implication if P is false. There is no state of Q that would deny that the implication still held. And so the state of the implication is True in those last cases because there is nothing in the state of P or Q that would deny the veracity of the implication.

threads.com:
The human internal clock runs slow, typically on a 25-26 hour cycle. In order to synchronize to the 24-hour day-night cycle, our body recieves external cues to advance (shorten) or delay (extend) our internal clocks and stay synchronized with the sun. These cues, typically light and melatonin levels, are called "zeitgebers" and can cause an advance or delay in our circadian cycle depending on the time of day.

Melatonin is commonly prescribed for people with DSPD ("late risers") and N24SWD. The instruction is usually to take it in the evening, but based on this Phase Response Curve (PRC), wouldn't you want to take it at lunch instead? Assuming you naturally wake up at 8am, this graph indicates that just before 1pm would be the best time to advance your sleep cycle, and that any later you risk having residual melatonin levels in the evening, causing a delay.

Likewise, shouldn't bright light exposure start 2-3 hours /before/ you wake up, since that's where the peak is?

Sleep cycle/chronobiology thread go

the reason in this case is that you have artificial lighting that doesn't regulate itself
if you were to spend your time in an environment where the light followed the natural course of sunlight, you'd see that your circadian rhythm is the same as that of everyone else: almost exactly 24 hours
>>14997475
the entire point is to find the length of the circadian cycle in the absence of externally enforced light cues
the original experiments that tried this let people adjust lighting as they saw fit, causing a delay in the cycle
later experiments eliminating this factor found the circadian cycle in the absence of externally enforced light changes to be almost exactly 24 hours long (again, only ~10 minutes of variation off at most typically)

threads.name: YWPTS
threads.com:
Method for Rapid/Early Detection of Internal Bleeding by Analysis of Laser Spectroscopy-Indicated Adrenaline Levels

A desire for improved methods for early detection of battlefield injuries that is both automated and low-cost has been expressed. It has been assessed that there is room for improvement, naturally, in battlefield triage procedures that could, if addressed, mitigate the fatality rate for battlefield injuries.

Although advanced equipment is often available in-theater, limited resources dictate that individuals suffering from internal bleeding be identified accurately and early. Internal bleeding accounts for a high percentage of preventable fatalities where battlefield conditions and limited resources preclude the possibility of testing each and every soldier affected by an explosion, for example, for internal bleeding as one would routinely do when applicable in civilian hospitals. An accurate and affordable mechanism for detecting internal bleeding would enable us to increase the effectiveness of battlefield triage.

last_replies.name: YWPTS
last_replies.com:
LASER light can be used to spectroscopically identify nearly any chemical compound. Ordinarily, this technology is used to measure concentrations of potentially hazardous gasses in the air, but it can easily be adapted to serve the same function in aqueous environments including within the human body. Along these lines, we already use IR absorbtiometry to measure blood oxygen levels using affordable devices that clip to a patient's finger. These devices produce results in seconds and can provide ongoing, real-time data concerning blood oxygen levels.

I propose that a device with a similar form-factor can be similarly clipped to a patient's finger to fulfill the function of measuring relative levels of adrenaline over time in the first couple of hours after a traumatic injury.

Adrenaline, like any other compound, has a unique spectroscopic signature, absorbing some frequencies of light more than others. Rather than simply using spectroscopy to discern the mere presence of this hormone (obviously present in some small quantity in any person) a hyper-accurate measurement of the level of contrast of adrenaline's spectral lines could be used to non-invasively measure the adrenaline level in a section of a patient's finger.

When blood is being lost by the body gradually (as with internal bleeding,) blood pressure, thanks to natural mechanisms to maintain volemic homeostasis, remains constant and does not diminish except in end-stage hypovolemia. For most of the hours-long process of succumbing to internal bleeding, blood pressure remains constant until the very end, offering field medical personnel few clues to the hidden danger.

last_replies.name: YWPTS
last_replies.com:
The primary mechanism the body employs to maintain this static ideal blood pressure is to secrete gradually increasing levels of adrenaline to constrict the blood vessels and maintain a stable pressure. While biologically the right thing to do, this compensation mechanism masks internal bleeding with respect to the use of blood pressure monitoring to identify the condition.

Rather than utilizing blood pressure monitoring for this purpose, I propose that that a LASER spectroscopy-based measurement of real-time adrenaline levels in parts per trillion can be used to diagnose internal bleeding accurately and in the early stages.

A soldier on the battlefield, for instance, would expect to have a rush of adrenaline immediately after sustaining an injury. Anything ranging from pain to anxiety could cause levels to spike, potentially making the cause of adrenaline fluctuations difficult to divine.

Once a soldier arrives in triage, morphine may be administered and more normative adrenaline level patterns can re-assert themselves. Even at this stage, some random fluctations in adrenaline levels could be easily expected to be measured by this proposed detector.

last_replies.name: YWPTS
last_replies.com:
To cut through the noise, a simple algorithm that looks at the moving average level of adrenaline over a short (10s,) medium (45s,) and long (5m) period could be used to determine which increases are caused by pain, which by anxiety, and which by blood loss, with the increases in adrenaline associated with blood loss being the most gradual of those three primary causes.

Any patient that has a long term upward trend in adrenaline after being at least mildly sedated (at least a 1pg/mL increase for each of four, 5-minute periods) would be red-flagged for probable internal bleeding and sent for further testing.

Although a clinically accurate measurment of adrenaline concentration would require calibration tailored to the individual, for this application, that level of calibration is unnecessary. All that is necessary here is that a relative baseline index value be established for a sedated, calm patient and that relative changes be discernible relative to the baseline value for that particular patient.

The Future Is Made in America

From an information theory perspective, wouldn't all deductive reasoning and inquiry generate absolutely zero information.

For example, if all Euclidean geometry can simply be derived from the five axioms, then all answers contain no information. We are not surprised at a to find out that, for 10X = 5, X = ½ here is no possible other outcome, our certainty is always = 1.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14996734

Take the for example the statement:

>18 × 12 + (152-103.28) ÷ 2^4 - (116-17.14) * 4.5^2 × 0.59 + 0.08485

Receiving this string gives you all the information to know that this statement is equivalent to -962.

This was long considered trivial. And it seems here like computation is not generating new information. We can paste the string into a computer and see the whole number version.

But there exist computable unambiguous strings that identify a number the way the above does that are not computable within the lifespans of human beings, or even star systems.

In those cases, it certainly seems like getting the whole number version of an answer is giving you information the string does not. If that is true, then completing the computation in the string seems like it should be creating new information.

If I want to know if there is a path I can take through 500 nodes without ever visiting the same node twice that is less than N length, I can write myself an algorithm that I know will be equivalent with my answer. However, my complete description of the answer fails to reduce my uncertainty about whether I can indeed travel between the nodes in a path of length N or less. I need to computation to be finished, and this will take a very long time.

However, if someone gives me a path meeting my criteria, I can check that it actually is a valid solution very quickly.

The amount of uncertainty reduced by the message then seems to be dependant on computation, no? If my string was easy to compute, it would indeed reduce my uncertainty, which in turn implies that the computation created new information, even though I already knew my algorithm was valid and would return a correct answer. Indeed, it was equivalent with the answer as a tautology in the same way the above string is equivalent with -962.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14997037
You're misunderstanding the problem. It isn't that "some obvious mathematical statements contain no information."

Consider the classic example of a message containing the outcomes of some coin tosses, our random variable. The message:

HH T H TTTT H TT HHH

Contains the same information about the random variable as the message:

2H T H 4T H 2T 3H

We would say the information content of the message is equivalent to the length of the message needed to transmit the outcomes given an optimal source coding of our random variable.

The problem comes up in more complex situations, where we can encode the events for our random variable(s) in ways that compress (or expand) the length of the message, but which require significant computational power to resolve.

The example I first encountered was a Leplace's Demon thought experiment. Suppose you have an isolated classical universe that just contains a single room, where two men are about to start flipping a coin. Suppose someone can gather exact information about every particle in said universe (this is a classical Leplacean example so we'll ignore quantum difficulties). This person then transmits a message to you that contains this information.

With this message, you now have information on the results of the coin tosses. All you have to do is evolve the system forward (the message contains instructions for doing this). However, your interlocutor has forgotten to provide you with your own Leplace's Demon for computing the future outcomes, thus you remain in the dark about the outcomes.

The question is, where have things broken down? It seems clear that the message made it to you and that it contained complete information about the outcome of the coin flips.

Then, assume your interlocutor recognizes his mistake and provides you with your own demon. You run the original message through the demon's software and get your answer. What changed?

>The only issue is that his lab is pretty new (currently 3 PhD students working under him and the lab was established in 2019-20)
That is sufficient for a small lab, I work for a lab/research group not much larger than this. Also, if he is innovative and has good funding lined up, it could be worthwhile. Also, younger professionals typically are more ambitious than well established profs because they still have to prove themselves, and are more hands-on too (but this may not necessarily be the case with everyone). In my opinion, having a mentor actually work with you/assist/advise you is more important than having a fancy name on the paperwork, even if that name can open more doors for you later on, but thats just my opinion. The newer professional will likely be able to help you develop actual skills/know-how but will not have the name recognition, while the more established professional will leave you on your own but will have better name recognition and connections.
Also, consider the time commitments, because face-to-face communications is very valuable - would you rather have someone who can meet with you 1-2 hours weekly or even more time per week, or someone who can give you 30 minutes max once in 2 weeks or a month?
Also, I cannot stress this enough - it really helps if you are on good terms with your advisor and like them as a person, than can make a big difference - do you like this guy? Because working for/with a likable person makes a big difference for your motivation

>>14994911
Katayama (1996) suggested that the heavy body-build of the Polynesians was the result of a special growth pattern ‘hypermorphism’, as conceived in heterochrony (e.g. McNamara, 1997). Katayama (1996) based his reasoning on the similarities of skeletal size and proportions, especially those of the extremities, between the Polynesians and a large Japanese individual with gigantism (a deceased Sumo wrestler, ‘Dewagatake’, Suzuki et al., 1986). Enlargement of the extremities is known to be one of the common clinical features of gigantism and acromegaly (e.g. Fitzgerald, 1992). Katayama (1996) suggested that the excessively developed body of the Polynesians is produced by their elongated juvenile and adolescent growths. Although gigantism is caused by an endocrinological disorder, genetic modifications mimicking it could have produced adaptive physical characteristics, which would have been selected for during the micro-evolutionary history of the Polynesians. It is possible that the Polynesians’ big feet, perhaps obtained by such growth mechanisms, would be adaptive in supporting their heavier bodies. The great RFL and RFB values (Table 2), the most distinctive features of their feet, indicate that the Tongans have long and wide feet even relative to their tall and heavy bodies.

Selection that occurred during such bottlenecks—caused, for example, by the windy climate—would be likely to favor the heavy body-build of the Polynesians. The genetic modification underlying such an adaptation could have resulted in a ‘hypermorphic’ growth pattern, which produced not only a heavy body-build but also the characteristically large feet of the Polynesians.

I am interested in philosophy of mind but there's no one in the field since the 1800s who considers consciousness as occurring from something that's not the brain. My personal favorite theory is integrated information theory. To answer your question about sight, your eyes detect visual information, but information has to project into different neural regions to be decoded so that shape, color, motion, and other perceptual features can be generated. Perceptual features then reintegrate into experience. The act of integration is what causes consciousness to occur.

i was a lead engineer on the sls for about 3 and a half years. honestly, it's pretty safe. i often heard the comment 'the apollo program never would have gotten off the ground with the nasa of today,' because the current culture at nasa is so safety-oriented. there are double, triple, and sometimes quadruple redundancies built in at various points, the tolerances for nominal levels are very tight, and we ran so many off-nominal simulations to come up with contingencies in the event of x or y.

>>14995983
this gets asked all the time and this
>>14996097
isn't the answer. it's the same reason we don't build cars from the 50s and 60s or make computers from the 50s and 60s...why would we? all of the tooling for those projects has been sold, scrapped, melted, lost, etc, long ago. it would cost just as much to "remake" the saturn V as it would to build a new rocket from scratch - and despite the hype about reusing shuttle parts the sls was very custom. the other thing people don't appreciate is the new technology that's in the sls, because it's never really explained. a car from 1930 would get you from a to b. a car from 2022 would do the same thing. to someone sitting outside and watching they might conclude the technology in both is pretty comparable, it's only to the people in the car and those involved in its construction that the differences are readily apparent. Same with rocketry. the sls has significantly improved guidance, communications, computing power, telemetry sensors and output, etc. now having said all that, i still think they should cancel the program and put the money to use elsewhere, like building a permanent lunar outpost.

threads.com: Ever heard of the near-vacuum of outer space? How about the nearer-vacuum of areas that physically make sense why they'd behave that way? There isn't an "actual" "vacuum of space". Space doesn't physically exist, so when we call it "space" or "outer space", we're typically conceptualizing it wrongly. Space is an abstract measurement only, like time, useful for observing and describing physics in an organized manner. It makes sense that an explosion in space would burn atmospheric elements, and cause a proportional vacuum effect local to the area for a time.
